curriculumTitle: Waco Surf STEM Academy: High-Frequency Field Research Rotation
overview: A refined, high-intensity rotation curriculum designed for UB/UBMS students in Texas (Dallas, Tarrant, Johnson counties). This curriculum breaks down complex hydrodynamics and environmental engineering concepts into 20 distinct, rapid-fire micro-modules (sprints). Students rotate through stations at the Waco Surf facility, covering Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics, and Engineering in 20-30 minute intervals. The curriculum is strictly aligned with HEA Title IV regulations for allowable costs and services, providing rigorous academic instruction in a field setting.
prerequisites: Completion of Algebra I; Recommended concurrent enrollment in Geometry or IPC (Integrated Physics and Chemistry).
totalDurationEstimate: 10 Hours (Split between Field Lab and Pre-Lab/Post-Lab analysis)

fieldTrips.name: Waco Surf Artificial Wave Facility
fieldTrips.location: Waco, TX (Accessible via I-35 from Dallas/Tarrant/Johnson)
fieldTrips.description: A controlled-environment artificial surf lagoon powered by pneumatic wave-generation technology. The facility allows for consistent, repeatable wave physics measurements not possible in ocean environments.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Primary laboratory site for data collection on wave frequency, amplitude, water chemistry, and fluid dynamics.

activities.title: Station 1: Wave Period Analysis
activities.description: Students measure the precise time interval between wave crests to determine the frequency of the wave generator.
teks: Physics 7(B): investigate and analyze characteristics of waves, including frequency.
texasStemStandards: STEM Level 2: Students use tools to collect data.

detailed: Explain that human reaction time is a source of error; encourage averaging.
Verify students are timing the same wave set (sets usually come in 3s).

brief: Start timer when Wave A hits the mark.
Stop when Wave B hits the mark.
detailed: Observe the wave generator 'hiss'.
Select a fixed visual marker on the wall.
Time 5 distinct wave sets and calculate the mean Period (T).

trioCompliance.justification: Provides rigorous academic instruction in Physics (oscillatory motion) utilizing field equipment.
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.405(a) - Allocable costs to the Federal award

activities.title: Station 2: Amplitude Measurement
activities.description: Visual triangulation of wave height against calibrated wall markers to understand energy displacement.
learningObjectives: Differentiate between wave height and amplitude.
teks: Physics 7(B): analyze amplitude.

brief: Use pool wall markers as Y-axis.
detailed: Explain that amplitude is from the 'Still Water Line' up to the crest, not trough to crest (which is wave height).
Using the binoculars, watch the water level against the metric ruler on the far wall.
Record the baseline water level.
Record the max height of the wave.
Subtract baseline from max to find Amplitude.

trioCompliance.justification: Application of geometry and measurement in a real-world setting.

activities.title: Station 3: Velocity Calculation
activities.description: Calculation of wave speed using distance markers and time data to verify wave equations.
learningObjectives: Verify velocity using v = f * lambda.
teks: Physics 4(A): calculate average speed using distance and time.

detailed: Ensure students understand that the water molecules aren't moving at this speed, the energy pulse is.
Locate Marker A and Marker B (Distance = 10m).
Start timer when crest passes A, stop at B.
Calculate Velocity (meters/second).
Compare this to the machine setting listed on the control board.

trioCompliance.justification: Kinematics instruction aligning with state physics standards.
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.403(a) - Necessary for performance of award

activities.title: Station 4: Wave Decay & Friction
activities.description: Students measure wave height at the source vs. the shore to calculate energy loss due to friction and turbulence.
teks: Physics 6(F): investigate energy transformations and conservation.

brief: Compare Station 2 data with shoreline data.
detailed: Discuss the Law of Conservation of Energy: The wave height decreases, so where did the energy go? (Heat, Sound, Sand displacement).
Record wave height at the break-point (shore).
Compare with the deep-water height from Station 2.
Calculate the % decrease in height.
Hypothesize the friction coefficient of the pool floor.

trioCompliance.justification: Advanced thermodynamics and energy conservation research.

activities.title: Station 5: Wavelength Estimation
activities.description: Visual estimation of the distance between two simultaneous crests to model spatial frequency.
learningObjectives: Estimate wavelength in a non-static medium.
teks: Physics 7(B): characteristics of waves including wavelength.

brief: Use surfers or buoys as scale reference.
detailed: If a surfer is 6ft tall, how many 'surfers' fit between the two wave crests?
Find a moment when Wave A and Wave B are both visible.
Use the fence posts (known distance) or a surfer to estimate the meters between crests.
Check your work: Velocity divided by Frequency should equal Wavelength.

trioCompliance.justification: Core physics curriculum alignment regarding wave properties.

activities.title: Station 6: Bathymetry Slope Math
activities.description: Using basic surveying to calculate the slope of the pool floor (beach entry) to understand wave breaking mechanics.
learningObjectives: Understand how depth affects wave shape (breaking).
teks: Geometry 5(A): investigate patterns to make conjectures about geometric relationships.
Physics 7(D): investigate behaviors of waves including reflection and refraction.

brief: Perform in shallow wading area only.
detailed: Ensure students do not go deeper than waist height for safety.
Discuss how the slope determines if a wave 'spills' or 'plunges'.
Start at water's edge (Depth = 0).
Extend tape measure 5 meters into water (Run).
Measure depth at the 5m mark (Rise).
Calculate Slope = Rise/Run.
Calculate Angle = tan^-1(Rise/Run).

activities.title: Station 7: Total Volume Estimation
activities.description: Using geometric decomposition to estimate the total water volume in the lagoon for chemical treatment analysis.
learningObjectives: Decompose complex shapes into rectangles and triangles.
Calculate volume and convert to gallons.
teks: Geometry 11(D): apply formulas for volume.
Chemistry 2(G): dimensional analysis.

detailed: Explain that 'acre-feet' is a common large-scale water measurement, but we are using gallons.
Break the pool shape into 3 rectangles and 2 triangles.
Estimate the volume of each section in Cubic Meters.
Sum the volumes.
Convert Total Cubic Meters to Gallons (1 m^3 = 264 gallons).

trioCompliance.justification: Complex dimensional analysis and mathematical modeling.

activities.title: Station 8: Flow Rate Analysis
activities.description: Observing filtration return jets to calculate flow rate and turnover efficiency.
teks: Environmental Systems 5(B): identify water quantity and usage.

brief: Use a water return pipe accessible from deck.
detailed: Turnover rate is the time it takes to filter the entire volume of the pool once.
Place bucket under flow.
Time how long to fill 5 gallons.
Calculate Gallons Per Minute (GPM).
Divide Total Volume (from Station 7) by GPM to find minutes required to filter the whole pool.

activities.title: Station 9: pH Field Test
activities.description: Rapid testing of water acidity using strips or digital meters to ensure bather safety.
learningObjectives: Determine pH level of a solution.
Understand the logarithmic scale of pH.
teks: Chemistry 10(H): understand and differentiate among acid-base reactions.

detailed: Explain that pH is logarithmic; pH 7 is 10x more acidic than pH 8.
Take a sample from 1ft depth.
Dip strip for 2 seconds.
Wait 15 seconds.
Compare to color chart.
Is the water basic, acidic, or neutral?

trioCompliance.justification: Basic chemistry lab skills in the field.

activities.title: Station 10: Chlorine & UV Interaction
activities.description: Testing free chlorine levels in sunny vs. shaded areas to analyze photolysis.
learningObjectives: Analyze the effect of UV radiation on chemical bonds.
teks: Chemistry 11(A): describe the unique role of water in chemical and biological systems.

detailed: UV light breaks the bond between Chlorine and the pathogen, or degrades the Chlorine itself.
Use the DPD kit to measure Free Chlorine in the deep end.
Measure Free Chlorine in the shallow, sunny end.
Calculate the difference.
Explain why UV radiation degrades chlorine.

activities.title: Station 11: Thermal Stratification
activities.description: Measuring temperature differences at varying depths to map the thermocline.
learningObjectives: Understand specific heat capacity of water.
teks: Physics 6(E): describe how the macroscopic properties of a thermodynamic system change.

brief: Use probe on string for deep readings.
detailed: Water is denser when cold (to a point), creating layers.
Measure temp at surface.
Drop probe to 1 meter depth.
Record temp.
Is there a significant difference? Why or why not (consider mixing/pumps)?

activities.title: Station 12: Turbidity Assessment
activities.description: Assessing water clarity using a Secchi disk to evaluate filtration efficiency.
teks: Environmental Systems 9(B): analyze test results for water quality.

detailed: High turbidity implies poor filtration or high biological load.
Slowly lower the black/white disk into the water.
Stop exactly when you can no longer distinguish the pattern.
Measure the length of string submerged.
Relate this to bather load today.

activities.title: Station 13: Drag Test - Surface Area
activities.description: Towing objects of different sizes to measure fluid resistance.
learningObjectives: Demonstrate relationship between surface area and drag.
teks: Physics 4(D): calculate the effect of forces.

brief: Pull objects at constant walking pace.
detailed: Consistency of speed is key. If they speed up, drag increases exponentially.
Attach spring scale to the small plate.
Drag it through water at a steady walk.
Record Newtons of force.
Repeat with large plate.
Calculate: Did doubling the area double the force?

trioCompliance.justification: Fluid dynamics experiment using force measurement.

activities.title: Station 14: Drag Test - Hydrodynamics
activities.description: Comparing a block vs. a streamlined shape (fin) to analyze drag coefficients.
learningObjectives: Compare drag coefficients of different shapes.
teks: Physics 4(D): analyze forces.

detailed: Point out the eddies behind the square block (low pressure zone) which creates drag.
Drag the square block and measure force.
Drag the teardrop/fin shape and measure force.
Observe the water behind each shape. Which is smoother?
Explain why fish are shaped the way they are.

activities.title: Station 15: Buoyancy & Density
activities.description: Testing whether specific materials float or sink to apply Archimedes' Principle.
teks: Physics 2(E): design and implement investigative procedures.

detailed: The lagoon is freshwater. Would these results change in the ocean? (Yes, salt water is denser, things float better).
Hold the cubes. Rank them by mass.
Place them in water. Which float?
Explain why a heavy steel ship floats (hint: it's mostly air inside, lowering average density).

activities.title: Station 16: Pneumatic Sound Analysis
activities.description: Using a decibel meter app to analyze the sound intensity of the pneumatic air release.
teks: Physics 7(A): examine wave propagation in media (air).

brief: Stand at safe distance from caissons.
detailed: Sound drops off by the inverse square law. If you double the distance, intensity drops to 1/4.
Open dB meter app.
Measure the ambient noise.
Measure the peak volume of the air release hiss.
Measure the peak volume of the wave impact.
Are these levels safe for long-term exposure (>85dB)?

trioCompliance.justification: Physics of sound and industrial safety.

activities.title: Station 17: Pump Station Power Estimation
activities.description: Reading motor plates/specs to calculate energy usage and operational cost.
teks: Physics 6(A): investigate and calculate work and power.

detailed: Real world connection: How much does it cost to run this wave for 1 hour?
Formula: Watts = Volts x Amps.
Calculate total kW.
Multiply by hours of operation to find kWh.
Calculate daily cost at $0.12/kWh.
Reflect on the energy intensity of recreation.

activities.title: Station 18: Concrete & Material Science
activities.description: Examining the pool liner for wear, texture, and friction to understand materials science.
learningObjectives: Understand material selection for aquatic environments.
teks: Chemistry 4(A): differentiate between physical and chemical changes.

detailed: Too smooth = slip hazard. Too rough = 'pool toe' (abrasion). It must be perfect.
Look at the pool floor through the magnifier.
Is it porous or sealed? Why?
Look for signs of chemical erosion (pitting).
Why is polymer used instead of just concrete?

activities.title: Station 19: Physiological Response
activities.description: Measuring heart rate before and after water entry to analyze mammalian dive reflex and exertion.
teks: Biology 10(A): describe the interactions that occur among systems.

detailed: Discuss Homeostasis: the body trying to maintain temperature and oxygen levels.
Record BPM while sitting dry.
Enter water and tread water/swim for 2 minutes.
Immediately record BPM.
Record how many minutes it takes to return to resting rate (Recovery Time).

activities.title: Station 20: Data Symposium & Career Synthesis
activities.description: A final rapid-fire session where groups aggregate data and discuss observed careers.
learningObjectives: Identify STEM careers involved in facility operation.
teks: Scientific Research and Design 2(E): organize and evaluate data.

detailed: Facilitate a discussion on 'Sources of Error'. Why did Group A get different results than Group B?
Share your group's calculated Wave Velocity and pH.
Identify 3 STEM jobs required to build or run this surf park.
What would you do differently next time to get better data?
